pgTitle: List of Scheduled Monuments in Neath Port Talbot

rows.text: Buarth y Gaer, Mynydd y Gaer
Iron Age hillfort some 100m across, with a Bronze Age burial cairn inside, at the highest point.
Possibly chambered tomb, but it is uncertain if it is a manmade structure
Camp 280m S of Melin Court Brook
Three Round Cairns on Carn Caca
Three Round Cairns on Mynydd Drumau
A round barrow (burial mound) 9m across, on the summit of a small hill

Large sandstone undressed block, metres (ft) high and metres (ft) across. It is in a field adjoining the M4, but tree growth means it is no longer visible from the motorway. Also called Ty-Du and Ty'n Cellar Standing Stone.
An unfinished defensive ringwork on the edge of the scarp, next to the Roman Camp
Round Cairn with Cist on Mynydd Drumau
Round barrow which contained burnt bones, excavated in 1921
Roman Marching Camp South West of Melin Court Brook
Roman Marching Camp South East of Coelbren Fort
Rectangular Roman camp metres (yd) from east to west, and metres (yd) wide, defined by bank and ditch cut into the rocky ground, on the top of a broad ridge on the hill above Tonna.
Medieval Church, now in the overgrown corner of the large churchyard. It was replaced by a newer church in the same churchyard in 1882, but only became derelict after a fire in 1954
Coed Ddu house platforms and enclosure
Two Platform Houses 1600m SE of Blaen-Nant Farm
House Platforms West of Dyffryn Wood
Deserted Rural Settlement North of Foel Fynyddau
Blast furnaces on the western edge of Cwmgwrach, built in 1839-42 to use anthracite-fired 'hot-blast' method of iron smelting. Also called Yr Wenallt.
Built in 1823 to cross the River Neath and link the Tennant and Neath Canals. With 10 stone arches it is the longest aqueduct in South Wales.
Industrial site originating with waterpowered metalworking in 1584. Now open to the public
Waun y Coed Colliery Branch Canal and Tramroad Incline
Blast furnaces and engineering works, with a forge and rolling mill upstream. It was in use from 1790s to 1885
Dam on the river Clydach, to provide a constant water supply for the ironworks waterwheel. Built in 1840
Remains of Blast Furnaces at Banwen
Completed in 1825 to provide water to power the waterwheels of Cwmafon steelworks, it is now a cycle and pedestrian routeway
Remains of Blast Furnace at Melin Court
Glyncorrwg Mineral Railway (Parsons Folly) Section on Cefn Morfudd
Remains of Lock and Dry Dock at Pantyffynnon
Designed by Brunel in 1861, this had an experimental buoyant lockgate system between the tidal and inner docks
Cae'r Mynydd Ventilation Furnace and Mine
Canal Aqueduct over the River Twrch, Ystalyfera
Anthracite coalmine opened by the nationalised British Coal Board in 1957, and worked out 10 years later. It was a drift mine, driven sideways into the hillside south of Glynneath.
Chain Home Low Radar Station, Margam
